person.note: Although she is not designated his wife, they appear together in one inscription in Elijah’s Cave, where often family members are listed together.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the Semitic ו suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.5.1, p. 28.
The amulet was obviously written by a Jew, but the client need not have been one, see vol. 4, Introduction 6.7, p. 37.

state.note: Alexander (8)’s daughter, of Arca in Lebanon

person.note: Reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

In Greek – ἀπὸ τῆς συναγ ̓́Αρκα[ου Λι]βάνου (of the Synagogue of Arca in Lebanon). Arca is situated north of Tripolis. On such designations based on provenance see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
The inscription mentions a synagogue see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.4, p. 39; and is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35.
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

Reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For the form ̓Αλέξας for women, see vol. 1, under Alexandra (6) G/F, p. 313. On the interchange of the feminine ας and ης suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3, pp. 12-13.
Which is the City of Samaria.
The inscription was found in a Samaritan synagogue, see Introduction 6.1.4.
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

On the interchange of ι and αι as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15. The fall of the ε may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. It may however be intentional, and stem from a misunderstanding of the Greek name (around the goddess) an assimilated to other Greek suffixes.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
Most editors suggest that the Hebrew and Aramaic inscriptions on the Temple Mount are late but see Introduction 6.4.1.
See previous note.

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. I guess this could also be reconstructed differently though I have no ideas of my own. The editor claims this is “diminutif d’̓Αναστασία, appartient à une famille de diminutives encore usités dans le grec modern: ̓Ελένκω, pour ̓Ελένη …etc.”
The exact location of this inscription is unknown. The editor claimed it was found somewhere between Jaffa and Gaza.

Jewishness could be suggested based on husband’s name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. This a dedication of a ἁγίου τόπου (Holy Place) which could be a church, but could also be a synagogue, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.4, p. 42.
The inscription is dated according to the indictions, but this does not always help, see Introduction 7.5.4.2. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 3, under Anastasia (1) G/F, p. 403. The editor thinks this is the epitaph of the previous but since the provenance of both is uncertain and the reading of the previous name so problematic (see above, n. 5), this is not at all necessary.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. The exact location of this inscription is unknown. The editor claimed it was found somewhere between Jaffa and Gaza.

person.note: Jewishness indicated by the mention of a σιναγα[γων] (synagogue), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.1.2.2, p. 38.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
In Greek – σταθμούχων. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3.
In Syria.

This is an inn inscription. It bears Hebrew names and a biblical quotation (1 Sam 16:4). Yet its tentative date (and the popularity of the name Johannes among Christians) puts its Jewish character into question, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. IJO 3, App19 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
Jewishness indicated by the fact that the amulet is in Jewish characters, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
On the interchange of ιand ει as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15. For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
Near Nablus, in Samaria.
This sarcophagus is part of a Mausoleum that was identified as Samaritan because of location and nature of find, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
This is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city. There are no indications, that the inscription is Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The fall of the ε may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. On the interchange of η and ι as part of the phenomenon of iotacism see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15.
This is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city. There are no indications, that the inscription is Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In Greek – πιστή. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.7.1.
The editor saw the inscription in Jaffa. He says it comes from Caesarea, but it was found with Jewish epitaphs from Jaffa with similar formula.
Jewishness could be suggested based on provenance, but see previous note.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2, but the reading is not certain.
This is a reasonable transliteration see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

For the dating of this synagogue see Introduction 7.5.3.

This is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city. There are no indications, that the inscription is Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.

This is my reading, according to the photograph. The editor suggested it reads “Provincia” (see ibid., 13*), which is obviously a translation. For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
The inscription was found on a lintel, probably of a burial cave.
In Lower Galilee.
The inscription was found in Galilee, a predominantly Jewish region, but it is an ἑις Θέος inscription, see Introduction 6.1.6.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
So in BS2:125. BS 2:113 has Ε̓μαθία. In the interchange of ι and ει see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21.

Jewishness indicated by the fact that the inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.5.3, pp. 46-7.
In Greek – πενθερᾶς.
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

On the initial ε as part of a reverse transliteration from Jewish characters into Greek see Introduction 2.3.1. For the interchange of ω and ο see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 15. On the interchange of η and ι as part of the phenomenon of iotacism see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15.

In the Upper Jordan Valley.
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.
For the interchange of ω and ο see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 15. On the interchange of ιand ει as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
In Greek – ποτὲ δούλην τῶν βασιλήων (once slave of kings).

If she is a freed slave, she may have come back to her Jewish homeland in Palestine. Or she could have been the freed slave of King Agrippa, as suggested by Schwabe, Journal of Juristic Papyrology 4 (1950) 309-15, in which case she may have converted. But we must not forget that this is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
She is described in the text as ̓Ιταλικὴν τὸ γενός(of Italian descent).
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
Reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
This is a Samaritan synagogue, see Introduction 6.1.4.
For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.

In Greek – ̓Ετῶν ο ́. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In Greek – Πτολεμαιῖτις. On such designations based on provenance see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
Jewishness suggested based on the theophoric names of father and daughter (but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52), and on their provenance (Palestine), but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.8.1, p. 54.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
On the interchange of η and ι as part of the phenomenon of iotacism see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15.
The amulet originates in the antiquities market. The dealer informed the buyer that it was found in the Hebron region.
Although the amulet derives from a region that was populated by Jews, there is nothing Jewish about it, as Lifschitz himself noted.

The text reads ̔Ηερά μ[ήτ]ηρ Μεγάλη. Lifschitz thinks the word ̔Ηεράstands for the adjective ἱερά (pious, not priestess) and translates “the pious mother Megale”. He wrote: “Le groupe des letters HEPA n’est pas le nom de la mere, elle s’appelait Mégalè; il faut donc supposer que l’adjectif ἱερά est ici employé dans le sens de “pieuse” ou peut-etre “défunte,” However, it could also be translated “Hiera, the great mother,” in which case Hiera and not Megale is the name. But all this is not decisive.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
This is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city. There are no indications, that the inscription is Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.

Lehmann & Holum write “the text might contain a matronymic, or might have commemorated several Jewish priests”. However, it could also mean, “priestess of Tasella”, in which case it is not a name, neither is it Jewish.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the fall of the suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.2.1.1, p. 10.
In Jewish characters – קירה (κύρα). On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.2.
On the dating of this synagogue see Introduction 7.5.3.
So in BS 2:136. On double and single consonants in Greek names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 16.
So in BS 2:137, see previous note.
In Greek – ματρώνα ... ἡ ἀπὸ Βίβλου (in Lebanon). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34. On the title see Introduction 3.1.3.2.
The inscription was found in a Jewish cemetery, in Palestine, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.5.7, pp. 49-50.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
In Greek – μιζοτέρας καὶ ἀπελευ(θ)έρας.
If she is a freed slave and buried in Jewish catacomb, we may assume (but need not be certain) that she was bought as non-Jewish and converted under the influence of her Jewish owners.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

Interpreted as a name by J.-L. Fournet, “À propos de PSI IX 1061 Descr.: Le nom du saunier et une formation méconnue d’anthroponymes féminins,” ZPE 135 (2001) 149. And see above, n. 3. For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.

person.note: The editors thought this is a title, and the name was not preserved in the inscription, but this could be the name, see above, n. 6. Interpreted as a name by J.-L. Fournet, “À propos de PSI IX 1061 Descr.: Le nom du saunier et une formation méconnue d’anthroponymes féminins,” ZPE 135 (2001) 149. And see above, n. 3.
This is an epitaph from Caesarea, which was a mixed city. There are no indications, that the inscription is Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.

On the interchange of υ and ου see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 16.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.

There is a question whether this is a name of a title. For its being a title speaks its appearance with a definite article (η), and its meaning – lady, mistress. For its being a name one could argue that if the first name is Septimia, rather than Timia, in which case it is a Greek name after a Latin one, and the definite article represents the expression: “who is (also).”
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the Semitic הנ suffix see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.3.7, p. 11.
The dealers who sold this amulet claims that it derives from Lebanon or Syria. Jewishness indicated by the Jewish characters in which the amulet is composed, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4.

person.note: Both forms appear in the amulet. The suggestion to prefer the second reading, and as this name, is mine. The editors preferred the first form and wrote about it: “Qoriel is well-known as a name of an angel”, ibid, p. 79 and bring examples for it in a magical text from the Cairo Genizah, and incantation bowls and Greek magical papyri. What it is doing here as the name of a woman they do not explain. However, I see the first form as a scribal error, see col. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20. The second letter may actually be read as a י, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.4, p. 31, and above, n. 3.
In Judea, south of Bethlehem.

The inscription was found in Tiberias. It may be assumed that Antiocheans who migrated from Syria to Tiberias in Palestine were Jews. However, IJO 3, App18 specifically denied the Jewishness of this inscription.

The amulet originates in the antiquities market. The dealer informed the buyer that it was found in the Hebron region.
The amulet derives from a region that was not particularly populated by Jews, and there is nothing Jewish about it, as Lifschitz himself noted.

The text reads ̔Ηερά μ[ήτ]ηρ Μεγάλη. Lifschitz thinks the word ̔Ηεράstands for the adjective ἱερά (pious, not priestess) and translates “the pious mother Megale”. However, it could also be translated “Hera, the great mother,” in which case Hera and not Megale is the name.

state.note: Marcus (4)’s wife, Joshua (31) Theodorus (13) and Daniel (4) Antoninus (3)’s mother

person.note: On this form see vol. 3, Nonna (2), p. 439.

The inscription is accompanied by a cross, so obviously it is Christian. Di Segni, ibid., suggested that, because of her sons’ names, her husband may have been a Jew or Samaritan, who converted to keep his job, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is dated according to the era of Gadara, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the Semitic י suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1.7, p. 24.
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.
In Greek in Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17. On the fall of the vowels see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.4, p. 13.
The inscription is in the Samaritan script, see Introduction 6.1.3.
For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
Reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

Although buried in Beth She‘arim, her son’s burial is an impressive mausoleum, in a burial site of catacombs. His epigram is also very pagan, mentioning Hades and the Moiras. I suggested elsewhere that he was not Jewish, see T. Ilan, in A. I. Baumgarten, H. Eshel, R. Katzoff and S.Tzoref(eds.), “Kever Israel: Since When do Jews Bury their Dead Separately and What did They do Beforehand?”Halakah in Light of Epigraphy(Göttingen 2010) 241-54.
See above, n. 3 .
On double and single consonants in Greek names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 16. For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
In Greek – ̓ετῶν θ´. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is probably (but not certainly) dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2,
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.
This is my reading. The editor did not understand this as a name. He read <τα> τῆς.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
Kibbutz in the north-western Negev.
My reading. Because the letters just before the name are missing, we could have here the Latin (Σεπ)τιμία.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 2.1.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

On double and single consonants in Greek names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 16. For the interchange of ω and ο see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 15. On the interchange of ιand ει as part of the iotacism phenomenon see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 15.
In Greek – ἀποθανούσης ἐτῶν λε ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
For unexpected declensions of names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7, pp. 16-7.
In Greek – τελευτεσάσης ἐτῶν ζ ́.On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
On this form see vol. 3, under Photia (1) G/F, p. 448.
The mosaic is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Introduction 6.2.1.7.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 2.1.

div.note: WGE did not know this name, but see LGPN IIIA, 94.
WGE did not know this form as a Greek name, but see LGPN II, 117.
Greek, WGE, 359. WGE finds this form recorded only as a ship’s name, but it could have been used for women as well. The name ̓́Ενα is recorded in LGPN V, 153.
WGE did not know this form but see LGPN I, 152 for the male name ̓Εντόλιος.
Greek, WGE, 362, only records the male name ̓Επαρχος, but see LGPN I, 154.
WGE, 412 records only the male name Ε̓μάθιος, but the female form must have existed next to it.
WGE did not know this form as a Greek name, but see LGPN IIIB, 163.
WGE, 426 records only the female name Ε̓σεβία, but this form must have existed next to it.
WGE 537 records the male ̔Ιέριος. LGPN IIIA, 216 records this (probably) female name.
WGE did not know this name, but see LGPN I, 284 for the male Λεοντίνης.
Greek, WGE 876. WGE does not list this as a personal name but see LGPN V, 286.
WGE 879 only records the male name, Μέγας. LGPN I, 301 and IIIA, 291 record the female name Μεγώand I, 301 also records the female name Μέγηα and perhaps also Μέγης.
WGE, 915 records the male name Μηναῖος.
WGE 918 records only the male name, Μητρόδοτος.
WGE 1133 only records the male name, Παρηγόριος, but see LGPN IIIB, 335.
WGE 1145 records only the male name, Παστοφόρος.

WGE 1528 only knew the male form Τιμίος (see vol. 3, under Timaius [1] G/M, p. 381) and LGPN (I, p. 440; II, p. 429; IIIA, p. 429; IIIB, 406) only records the male name Τιμίας but a female name obviously derives from it.
Greek, WEG, 1561 records the male form Τρωί̈λος.
